words.def: An a fortiori argument is an "argument from a stronger reason", meaning that because one fact is true, that a second related and included fact must also be true.
words.name: a fortiori

words.def: Divorce a mensa et thoro indicates legal separation without legal divorce.
words.name: a mensa et thoro

words.def: An argument derived from subsequent event
words.name: a posteriori

words.def: An argument derived from previous event
words.name: a priori

words.def: Regarding a court below in an appeal, either a court of first instance or an appellate court, known as the court a quo.
words.name: a quo

words.def: Concerning a case, a person may have received some funding from a 3rd party. This funding may have been considered ab extra.
words.name: ab extra

words.def: "Commonly used referring to the time a contract, statute, marriage, or deed become legal. e.g The couple was covered ab initio by her health policy."[1]
words.name: ab initio

words.def: "Presenting the negative portion of a plea when pleading at common by way a special traverse."[1]
words.name: absque hoc

words.def: The burden of proof falls to the plaintiff, claimant, or petitioner according to Roman law.
words.name: Actori incumbit probatio

words.def: Part of what proves criminal liability (with mens rea)
words.name: actus reus

words.def: Abbreviated from Cuius est solum eius est usque ad coelum et ad infernos which translates to "[for] whoever owns [the] soil, [it] is his all the way [up] to Heaven and [down] to Hell." The principle that the owner of a parcel of land also owns the air above and the ground below the parcel.
words.name: ad coelum

words.def: Generally signifies a solution designed for a specific problem or task, non-generalizable, and not intended to be able to be adapted to other purposes.
words.name: ad hoc

words.def: Attacking an opponent's character rather than answering his argument.
words.name: ad hominem

words.def: In agreement.
words.name: ad idem

words.def: To continue forever.
words.name: ad infinitum

words.def: Describes those designated to represent parties deemed incapable of representing themselves, such as a child or incapacitated adult.
words.name: ad litem

words.def: Used in tort law. Implies that the reward or penalty ought to correspond to the damage suffered or inflicted.
words.name: ad quod damnum

words.def: When an assembly adjourns without setting a date for its next meeting.
words.name: adjournment sine die

words.def: A formal statement of fact.
words.name: affidavit

words.def: A second identity living within a person.
words.name: alter ego

words.def: A person who offers information to a court regarding a case before it.
words.name: amicus curiae

words.def: Intention to contract
words.name: animus contrahendi

words.def: The subjective state of mind of the author of a crime, with reference to the exact knowledge of illegal content of his behaviour, and of its possible consequences.
words.name: animus nocendi

words.def: "In order to claim possessory rights, an individual must establish physical control of the res and the intention to possess (i.e. animus possidendi)"[2]
words.name: animus possidendi

words.def: "Wild animals, such as bees and homing pigeons, that by habit go 'home' to their possessor. Used when discussing ferae naturae."[2]
words.name: animus revertendi

words.def: Refers to the idea that one cannot be fairly judged unless the cases for and against them have been heard.
words.name: Audi alteram partem

words.def: Implies sincere good intention regardless of outcome.
words.name: bona fide

words.def: Indicates that a settlement to a dispute or issue has been reached, and the issue is now resolved.
words.name: Cadit quaestio

words.def: The justification for acts of war.
words.name: Casus belli

words.def: Force majeure, specifically a man-made inevitable accident (e.g. riots, strikes, civil war); ex: When H.M.S. Bounty was destroyed by Hurricane Sandy, October 29, 2012, casus fortuitus would describe the H.M.S. Bounty being at the wrong place when Hurricane Sandy came up the coast.HMS Bounty Sinks Compare vis major (see below).
words.name: casus fortuitus

words.def: When used by itself, refers to a qualification, or warning.
words.name: Caveat

words.def: In addition to the general warning, also refers to a legal doctrine wherein a buyer could not get relief from a seller for defects present on property which rendered it unfit for use.
words.name: Caveat emptor

words.def: A type of writ seeking judicial review.
words.name: Certiorari

words.def: More commonly rendered in English as "All other things being equal."
words.name: Ceteris paribus

words.def: The aggregate of marital property under a community property matrimonial regime.
words.name: communio bonorum

words.def: Delay in payment or performance on the part of both the debtor and the creditor
words.name: compensatio morae

words.def: Of sound mind. Also used in the negative "Non compos mentis", meaning "Not of sound mind".
words.name: compos mentis

words.def: An indispensable and essential action, condition, or ingredient.
words.name: Condicio sine qua non

words.def: Meeting of the minds, mutual assent, or concurrence of wills. Parties must be of one mind and their promises must relate to the same subject or object[3] Also consensus in idem.
words.name: consensus ad idem

words.def: Stipulates that when two or more persons arrive at a good faith agreement, the law will insist on that agreement being carried out.
words.name: consensus facit legem

words.def: Where no laws apply to a given situation, the customs of the place and time will have the force of law.
words.name: consuetudo pro lege servatur

words.def: Used in case citations to indicate that the cited source directly contradicts the point being made.
words.name: contra

words.def: Contracts so made are generally illegal and unenforceable.
words.name: contra bonos mores

words.def: Used when a court or tribunal hands down a decision that is contrary to the laws of the governing state.
words.name: contra legem

words.def: A contradiction in terms.
words.name: Contradictio in adjecto

words.def: Used in contract law to stipulate that an ambiguous term in a contract shall be interpreted against the interests of the party that insisted upon the term's inclusion. Prevents the intentional additions of ambiguous terminology from being exploited by the party who insisted on its inclusion.
words.name: contra proferentem

words.def: Refers to a legal proceeding without a judge, or with a judge who does not have proper jurisdiction.
words.name: coram non judice

words.def: A person cannot be convicted of a crime, unless it can be proven that the crime was even committed.
words.name: corpus delicti

words.def: The complete collection of laws of a particular jurisdiction or court.
words.name: corpus juris

words.def: The complete collection of civil laws of a particular jurisdiction or court. Also sometimes used to refer to the Code of Justinian.
words.name: corpus juris civilis

words.def: The complete collection of international law.
words.name: corpus juris gentium

words.def: An encyclopedia of US law drawn from US Federal and State court decisions.
words.name: corpus juris secundum

words.def: Forgery.
words.name: crimen falsi

words.def: Suggests that the perpetrator(s) of a crime can often be found by investigating those who would have benefited financially from the crime, even if it is not immediately obvious.
words.name: cui bono

words.def: Used in reference to the rights of property owners to the air above, and land below, their property.
words.name: cuius est solum eius est usque ad coelum et ad inferos

words.def: Specifies that larceny was taking place in addition to any other crime named. E.g. "trespass de bonis asportatis".
words.name: de bonis asportatis

words.def: Complete annihilation of a warring party, bringing about the end of the conflict.
words.name: debellatio

words.def: Assets of an estate remaining after the death (or removal) of the designated estate administrator. An "administrator de bonis non administratis" will then be appointed to dispose of these goods.
words.name: de bonis non administratis

words.def: Generally refers to a type of labor in which the worker is paid fully at the completion of each day's work.
words.name: de die in diem

words.def: Literally "from fact"; often used to mean something that is true in practice, but has not been officially instituted or endorsed. "For all intents and purposes". Cf. de jure.
words.name: de facto

words.def: At a future date.
words.name: de futuro

words.def: Often used to mean "start it all over", in the context of "repeat de integro".
words.name: de integro

words.def: Literally "from law"; something that is established in law, whether or not it is true in general practice. Cf. de facto.
words.name: de jure

words.def: Used in the context of "how the law should be", such as for proposed legislation.
words.name: de lege ferenda

words.def: Concerning the law as it exists, without consideration of how things should be.
words.name: de lege lata

words.def: Various legal areas concerning small amounts or small degrees.
words.name: de minimis

words.def: There must be a minimal level of substance or impact in order to bring a legal action.
words.name: de minimis non curat lex

words.def: Social convention that it is inappropriate to speak ill of the recently deceased, even if they were an enemy.
words.name: de mortuis nil nisi bonum

words.def: Often used in the context of "trial de novo" – a new trial ordered when the previous one failed to reach a conclusion.
words.name: de novo

words.def: Blasphemy is a crime against the State, rather than against God.
words.name: deorum injuriae diis curae

words.def: A statement given some weight or consideration due to the respect given the person making it.
words.name: dictum

words.def: Presumption that young children or persons with diminished mental capacity cannot form the intent to commit a crime.
words.name: doli incapax

words.def: Heavily used in the context of genocide in international law.
words.name: dolus specialis

words.def: Tame or domesticated animal. Also called mansuetae naturae. Opposite of ferae naturae (below)
words.name: domitae naturae

words.def: Gift causa mortis; "The donor, contemplating imminent death, declares words of present gifting and delivers the gift to the donee or someone who clearly takes possession on behalf of the donee. The gift becomes effective at death but remains revocable until that time."[2]
words.name: donatio mortis causa

words.def: Often spoken as "to give the benefit of the doubt."
words.name: dubia in meliorem partem interpretari debent

words.def: A "subpoena duces tecum" is a summons to produce physical evidence for a trial.
words.name: duces tecum

words.def: The concept that one is innocent until proven guilty.
words.name: ei incumbit probatio qui dicit

words.def: Known as a "canon of construction", it states that when a limited list of specific things also includes a more general class, that the scope of that more general class shall be limited to other items more like the specific items in the list.
words.name: ejusdem generis

words.def: Refers to rights or obligations that are owed towards all.
words.name: erga omnes

words.def: Abbreviation of et alii, meaning "and others".
words.name: et al.

words.def: Generally used in the sense of "and so forth".
words.name: et cetera

words.def: Abbreviation of et sequens, meaning "and the following ones". Used in citations to indicate that the cited portion extends to the pages following the cited page.
words.name: et seq.

words.def: Usually used instead of naming a man's wife as a party in a case.
words.name: et uxor

words.def: Usually used instead of naming a woman's husband as a party in a case.
words.name: et vir

words.def: Usually defined as "what is right and good." Used to describe the power of a judge or arbiter to consider only what is fair and good for the specific case, and not necessarily what the law may require. In courts, usually only done if all parties agree.
words.name: ex aequo et bono

words.def: Essentially meaning "before the event", usually used when forecasting future events.
words.name: ex ante

words.def: Where chair refers to authority or position. Authority derived from one's position.
words.name: ex cathedra

words.def: Often used in a "guilt by association" context.
words.name: ex concessis

words.def: The consequence of a crime or tort.
words.name: ex delicto

words.def: If a contract is blatantly and obviously incorrect or illegal, it can be considered void ex facie without any further analysis or arguments.
words.name: ex facie

words.def: Something done voluntarily and with no expectation a legal liability arising therefrom.
words.name: ex gratia

words.def: A principle in international law that unjust acts cannot create laws.
words.name: ex injuria jus non oritur

words.def: Something done or realized by the fact of holding an office or position.
words.name: ex officio

words.def: A decision reached, or case brought, by or for one party without the other party being present.
words.name: ex parte

words.def: Based on knowledge of the past.
words.name: ex post

words.def: Commonly said as "after the fact."
words.name: ex post facto

words.def: A retroactive law. E.g. a law that makes a past act illegal that was not illegal when it was done.
words.name: ex post facto law

words.def: When items are listed, anything not explicitly stated is assumed to not be included.
words.name: expressio unius est exclusio alterius

words.def: Commonly spoken as "by one's own accord."
words.name: ex proprio motu

words.def: Abbreviation of ex relatione. Used when the government brings a case that arises from the information conveyed to it by a third party ("relator").
words.name: ex rel

words.def: A party cannot bring a legal action for consequences of his own illegal act.
words.name: ex turpi causa non oritur actio

words.def: Usually abbreviated "e.g.".
words.name: exempli gratia

words.def: Term used in contract law to specify terms that are voided or confirmed in effect from the execution of the contract. Cf. ex nunc.
words.name: ex tunc

words.def: Term used in contract law to specify terms that are voided or confirmed in effect only in the future and not prior to the contract, or its adjudication. Cf. ex tunc.
words.name: ex nunc

words.def: Refers to things that are currently existing at a given point, rather than things that are no longer so.
words.name: extant

words.def: 1. an assured statement made; 2. completion of a will and all its parts to make it valid and legal; 3). book of facts and law presented in a Canadian court
words.name: factum

words.def: A type of contract wherein one party agrees to do work for the other, in order that the second party can then perform some work for the first in exchange.
words.name: facio ut facias

words.def: A concept in treaty law that prefers the maintaining of a contract over letting it expire for purely procedural reasons.
words.name: favor contractus

words.def: A suicide. This archaic term stems from English common law, where suicide was legally a felony, thus a person who committed suicide was treated as a felon for purposes of estate disposal.
words.name: felo de se

words.def: Wild animals residing on unowned property do not belong to any party in a dispute on the land. Opposite of domitae naturae (above)
words.name: ferae naturae

words.def: A warrant issued by a judge for some legal proceedings.
words.name: fiat

words.def: Often used as a motto, notably by Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor.
words.name: Fiat justitia et pereat mundus

words.def: Also sometimes a motto, a legal maxim that justice must be done regardless of the result otherwise.
words.name: fiat justitia ruat caelum

words.def: A writ ordering the local law enforcement to ensure that damages awarded by the court are properly recovered. A writ of execution.
words.name: fieri facias

words.def: When determining whether a chattel is a fixture: "size doesn't matter, how much or degree chattel is attached to 'land' and to 'what' "
words.name: fortis attachiamentum, validior praesumptionem

words.def: A concept wherein a court refuses to hear a particular matter, citing a more appropriate forum for the issue to be decided.
words.name: forum non conveniens

words.def: Emblements; in property law, a co-owner profitng from her or his fructus industriales is solely responsible for any losses that my occur.[2] (vs. fructus naturales, see below)
words.name: fructus industriales

words.def: Vegetation naturally growing from old roots (as pasturage) or from trees (as timber or fruit) (vs. fructus industriales, see above)
words.name: fructus naturales

words.def: Refers to having a sufficient legal basis to bring legal action.
words.name: fumus boni iuris

words.def: A person, court, statute, or legal document that has no legal authority, because its original legal purpose has been fulfilled.
words.name: functus officio

words.def: Specifies that a certain matter of law be covered by the most specific laws pertaining, in the event that broader laws conflict with the specific one.
words.name: generalia specialibus non derogant

words.def: The basic element or complaint of a lawsuit.
words.name: gravamen

words.def: An independent party appointed in family law disputes to represent parties that cannot represent themselves, such as minors, developmentally disabled, or elderly.
words.name: guardian ad litem

words.def: A writ used to challenge the legality of detention. Orders the detaining party to "have the (living) body" of the detained brought before the court where the detention will be investigated.
words.name: habeas corpus

words.def: A party considered to be the enemy of all nations, such as maritime pirates.
words.name: hostis humani generis

words.def: Abbreviation of id est, meaning "that is", in the sense of restating something that may not have been clear.
words.name: i.e.

words.def: Abbreviation of ibidem, meaning "in the same place. Used when citing sources, to indicate the cited source came from the identical location as the preceding one.
words.name: ibid.

words.def: Used in citations to indicate the cited source came from the same source as the preceding one, though not necessarily the same page or location. Cf. ibid.
words.name: idem

words.def: A principle that states that not having knowledge of a law is not an excuse for breaking it.
words.name: ignorantia juris non excusat

words.def: An authorization for a document to be printed. Used in the context of approval by a religious body or other censoring authority.
words.name: imprimatur

words.def: A legal proceeding conducted without the presence of one party is said to be conducted in absentia, e.g., trial in absentia or being sentenced in absentia.
words.name: in absentia

words.def: Often used in probate law, as well as for testimony in the sense of a dying declaration.
words.name: In articulo mortis

words.def: Conducted in private, or in secret. The opposite of in open court.
words.name: in camera

words.def: Conducted in open court. The opposite of in camera.
words.name: in curia

words.def: Actually existing in reality. Opposite of in posse.
words.name: in esse

words.def: In extended form, or at full length. Often used to refer to publication of documents, where it means the full unabridged document is published.
words.name: in extenso

words.def: In extreme circumstances. Often used to refer to "at the point of death."
words.name: in extremis

words.def: Caught in the actual act of committing a crime. Often used as a euphemism for a couple caught in the act of sexual intercourse, though it technically refers to being "caught in the act" of any misdeed.
words.name: in flagrante delicto

words.def: Someone unable to afford the costs associated with a legal proceeding. As this will not be a barrier to seeking justice, such persons are given in forma pauperis status (usually abbreviated IFP), wherein most costs are waived or substantially reduced.
words.name: in forma pauperis

words.def: Refers to things to come, or things that may occur later but are not so now. As in in futuro debts, i.e. debts which become due and payable in the future.
words.name: in futuro

words.def: Used when including text in a complaint verbatim, where its appearance in that form is germane to the case, or is required to be included.
words.name: in haec verba

words.def: A motion to a judge in a case that is heard and considered outside the presence of the jury.
words.name: in limine

words.def: Used to refer to a person or entity assuming the normal parental responsibilities for a minor. This can be used in transfers of legal guardianship, or in the case of schools or other institutions that act in the place of the parents on a day-to-day basis.
words.name: in loco parentis

words.def: A type of retroactive law that decriminalizes offenses committed in the past. Also known as an amnesty law.
words.name: in mitius

words.def: Used to mean "in every respect." Something applying to every aspect of a situation.
words.name: in omnibus

words.def: Used when both parties to a case are equally at fault.
words.name: in pari delicto

words.def: Refers to a situation where a law or statute may be ambiguous, and similar laws applying to the matter are used to interpret the vague one.
words.name: in pari materia

words.def: Used in the context of "directed at this particular person", refers to a judgement or subpoena directed at a specific named individual. Cf. in rem.
words.name: in personam

words.def: One who represents themselves in court without the [official] assistance of an attorney.
words.name: in prope persona

words.def: Alternate form of in prope persona. One who represents themselves in court without the [official] assistance of an attorney.
words.name: in propria persona

words.def: Used in the title of a decision or comment to identify the matter they are related to; usually used for a case where the proceeding is in rem or quasi in rem and not in personam (e.g. probate or bankrupt estate, guardianship, application for laying out a public highway) and occasionally for an ex parte proceeding (e.g. application for a writ of habeas corpus).
words.name: in re

words.def: Used in the context of a case against property, as opposed to a particular person. See also in rem jurisdiction. Cf. in personam.
words.name: in rem

words.def: Often used in the context of decisions or rulings about a property or thing "left in place" after the case as it was before.
words.name: in situ

words.def: Jointly and severally; where a group of persons share liability for a debt, such as co-signers to a loan, the debtor can sue a single party in solidum, that is, to recover the entire amount owed.
words.name: in solidum

words.def: A warning or threat to sue, made in the hopes of convincing the other party to take action to avoid a lawsuit.
words.name: in terrorem

words.def: A clause in a will that threatens any party who contests the will with being disinherited. Also called a no-contest clause.
words.name: in terrorem clause

words.def: Often used in copyright notices. Refers to distinctive markings that identify a piece of intellectual property.
words.name: indicia

words.def: An intimation about someone or something, made indirectly or vaguely suggesting the thing being implied. Often used when the implied thing is negative or derogatory.
words.name: innuendo

words.def: Used to indicate an item cited has been pulled from a larger or more complete list.
words.name: inter alia

words.def: A concept that during war, many illegal activities occur. Also taken to mean that in times of war, laws are suppressed, ostensibly for the good of the country.
words.name: inter arma enim silent leges

words.def: Refers to contract, debts, or other agreements made between parties who are not legal professionals.
words.name: inter rusticos

words.def: Refers to obligations between members of the same group or party, differentiated from the whole party's obligations to another party.
words.name: inter se

words.def: Refers to a gift or other non-sale transfer between living parties. This is in contrast to a will, where the transfer takes effect upon one party's death.
words.name: inter vivos

words.def: This term refers to a nation's territorial waters.
words.name: intra fauces terrae

words.def: Used in various contexts to refer to the legal foundation for a thing.
words.name: intra legem

words.def: Something done which requires legal authority, and the act is performed accordingly. Cf. ultra vires.
words.name: intra vires

words.def: An assertion given undue weight solely by virtue of the person making the assertion.
words.name: ipse dixit

words.def: Referring to a document or ruling that is being quoted by another.
words.name: ipsissima verba

words.def: Used in the context that one event is a direct and immediate consequence of another. "In and of itself."
words.name: ipso facto

words.def: By operation of law
words.name: ipso jure

words.def: A principle that calculation errors made by the court do not invalidate the judgement on a technicality. Also taken to mean that the judge does not tally up the arguments of both sides and decide in favor of the more numerous, but rather weighs all of the evidence without regard to the number of arguments made.
words.name: iudex non calculat

words.def: Concept that parties to a case do not need to define how the law applies to their case. The court is solely responsible for determining what laws apply.
words.name: jura novit curia

words.def: Appears at the end of an affidavit, where the party making the affirmation signs the oath, and the information on whom the oath was sworn before is placed.
words.name: jurat

words.def: Irrebuttable or conclusive presumptions of law. One cannot argue against, or try to otherwise refute these.
words.name: juris et de jure

words.def: Essentially: law.
words.name: jus

words.def: (1) Right of survivorship: In property law, on the death of one joint tenant, that tenant's interest passes automatically to the surviving tenant(s) to hold jointly until the estate is held by a sole tenant. The only way to defeat the right of survivorship is to sever the joint tenancy during the lifetime of the parties, the right of survivorshop takes priority over a will or interstate accession rules.[2] (2) (Civil law) right of accrual: Right of the beneficiary to succeed proportionately to a benefit that another beneficiary in the same will cannot or does not want to take.
words.name: jus accrescendi

words.def: Refers to legalities considered before entering into a war, to ensure it is legal to go to war initially. Not to be confused with ius in bello (q.v.), the "laws of war" concerning how war is carried out.
words.name: jus ad bellum

words.def: A codified set of laws concerning citizenry, and how the laws apply to them.
words.name: jus civile

words.def: Internationally agreed laws that bear no deviation, and do not require treaties to be in effect. An example is law prohibiting genocide.
words.name: jus cogens

words.def: Not actually referring to common law, this term refers to common doctrine and principles of civil law that underlie all aspects of the legal system.
words.name: jus commune

words.def: Customary law followed by all nations. Nations being at peace with one another, without having to have an actual peace treaty in force, would be an example of this concept.
words.name: jus gentium

words.def: Laws governing the conduct of parties in war.
words.name: jus in bello

words.def: Laws governing treaties and international agreements.
words.name: jus inter gentes

words.def: Laws common to all people, that the average person would find reasonable, regardless of their nationality.
words.name: jus naturale

words.def: Supposed right of the lord of an estate to take the virginity of women in his estate on their wedding night.
words.name: jus primae noctis

words.def: Right of a third-party beneficiary to sue in order to enforce a third-party contract (i.e., the opposite of privity of contract).
words.name: jus quaesitum tertio

words.def: Social law concept wherein citizenship of a nation is determined by having one or both parents being citizens.
words.name: jus sanguinis

words.def: Social law concept wherein citizenship of a nation is determined by place of birth.
words.name: jus soli

words.def: Arguments made by a third party in disputes over possession, the intent of which is to question one of the principal parties' claims of ownership or rights to ownership.
words.name: jus tertii

words.def: A situation arising that is not covered by any law. Generally used in International Law, as all countries codify according to their own systems of law.
words.name: lacunae

words.def: Illustrates that laws are made, are in force for a period, and then become obsolete.
words.name: leges humanae nascuntur, vivunt, moriuntur

words.def: Forfeiture clause for nonperformance of a contract, especially (1) a provision that a pledge shall be forfeited if a loan is defaulted, or (2) a condition that money paid on a contract of sale shall be forfeited and the sale rescinded if outstanding payments are defaulted. Also known as a pactum commissorium.
words.name: lex commissoria

words.def: Alternate form of jus commune. Refers to common facets of civil law that underlie all aspects of the law.
words.name: lex communis

words.def: The law as it has been enacted
words.name: lex lata

words.def: The law of the country, state, or locality where the matter under litigation took place. Usually used in contract law, to determine which laws govern the contract.
words.name: lex loci

words.def: More recent law overrules older ones on the same matter.
words.name: lex posterior derogat priori

words.def: A law cannot make something illegal that was legal at the time it was performed. See ex post facto law.
words.name: lex retro non agit

words.def: Law that specifically codifies something, as opposed to common law or customary law.
words.name: lex scripta

words.def: Where several laws apply to the same situation, the more specific one(s) take precedence over more general ones.
words.name: lex specialis derogat legi generali

words.def: An aspect of a unanimous voting system, whereby any member can end discussion on a proposed law.
words.name: liberum veto

words.def: A language common to an area that is spoken by all, even if not their mother tongue. Term derives from the name given to a common language used by traders in the Mediterranean basin dating from the Middle Ages.
words.name: lingua franca

words.def: Refers to requesting a legal dispute be heard that is also being heard by another court. To avoid possibly contradictory judgements, this request will not be granted.
words.name: lis alibi pendens

words.def: Often used in the context of public announcements of legal proceedings to come. Compare pendente lite (below).
words.name: lis pendens

words.def: Shorthand version of Lex locus delcti commissi. The "scene of the crime".
words.name: locus delicti

words.def: The location where a cause of action arose.
words.name: locus in quo

words.def: When one party withdraws from a contract before all parties are bound.
words.name: locus poenitentiae

words.def: The right of a party to appear and be heard before a court.
words.name: locus standi

words.def: A condition of being fraudulent or deceptive in act or belief.
words.name: mala fide

words.def: evil acts are distinguished from evil purposes[4] crimes are distinguished by the intention[5]
words.name: maleficia propositis distinguuntur

words.def: Something considered a universal wrong or evil, regardless of the system of laws in effect.
words.name: malum in se

words.def: Something wrong or illegal by virtue of it being expressly prohibited, that might not otherwise be so.
words.name: malum prohibitum

words.def: A writ issue by a higher court to a lower one, ordering that court or related officials to perform some administrative duty. Often used in the context of legal oversight of government agencies.
words.name: mandamus

words.def: A body of water under the jurisdiction of a state or nation, to which access is not permitted, or is tightly regulated.
words.name: mare clausum

words.def: A body of water open to all. Typically a synonym for International Waters, or in other legal parlance, the "High Seas".
words.name: mare liberum

words.def: One of the requirements for a crime to be committed, the other being actus reus, the guilt act. This essentially is the basis for the notion that those without sufficient mental capability cannot be judged guilty of a crime.
words.name: mens rea

words.def: A person's particular way of doing things. Used when using behavioral analysis while investigating a crime. Often abbreviated "M.O."
words.name: modus operandi

words.def: Delay in payment or performance in the part of the creditor or obligor
words.name: mora accipiendi

words.def: Delay in payment or performance in the part of the debtor or the obligee
words.name: mora solvendi

words.def: Gift or trust that is made in contemplation of death
words.name: mortis causa

words.def: That which is the usual custom has the force of law.
words.name: mos pro lege

words.def: Motions offered at the start of a trial, often to suppress or pre-allow certain evidence or testimony.
words.name: motion in limine

words.def: A caution to a reader when using one example to illustrate a related but slightly different situation. The caution is that the reader must adapt the example to change what is needed for it to apply to the new situation.
words.name: mutatis mutandis

words.def: Shortened version of ne exeat repiblica: "let him not exit the republic". A writ to prevent one party to a dispute from leaving (or being taken) from the court's jurisdiction.
words.name: ne exeat

words.def: Prohibition against double jeopardy. A legal action cannot be brought twice for the same act or offense.
words.name: ne bis in idem

words.def: Quasi-contractual obligation arising from good works affecting other people, obliging the benefited party (dominus negotii) to reimburse the gestor for the cost that was used in doing good works
words.name: negotiorum gestio

words.def: Nobody can bring a case that stems from their own illegal act
words.name: nemo auditur propriam turpitudinem allegans

words.def: If someone purchases something that the seller has no right to (such as stolen property), the purchaser will likewise have no legal claim to the thing bought.
words.name: nemo dat quod non habet

words.def: In the past it was thought that it included just two rules namely (1) nemo debet esse judex in propria causa (no one shall be a judge in his own case)[clarification needed]
words.name: nemo debet esse iudex in propria

words.def: Prevents conflict of interest in courts. Often invoked when there is really no conflict, but when there is even the appearance of one.
words.name: nemo judex in sua causa

words.def: A purchaser of stolen goods will not become the rightful owner thereof, since the seller himself was not the owner to begin with.
words.name: nemo plus iuris ad alium transferre potest quam ipse habet

words.def: A judgement rendered in the absence of a plea, or in the event one party refuses to cooperate in the proceedings.
words.name: nihil dicit

words.def: A decree that does not enter into force unless some other specified condition is met.
words.name: nisi

words.def: Refers to the court of original jurisdiction in a given matter.
words.name: nisi prius

words.def: A statement from the prosecution that they are voluntarily discontinuing (or will not initiate) prosecution of a matter.
words.name: nolle prosequi

words.def: A type of plea whereby the defendant neither admits nor denies the charge. Commonly interpreted as "No contest."
words.name: nolo contendere

words.def: In the case where a contract imposes specific obligations on both parties, one side cannot sue the other for failure to meet their obligations, if the plaintiff has not themselves met their own.
words.name: non adimpleti contractus

words.def: not having mental capacity to perform some legal act
words.name: non compos mentis

words.def: Refers to information given by one who is not supposed to give testimony, such as an attorney bringing up new information that did not come from a witness. Such information is typically nullified.
words.name: non constat

words.def: A method whereby a signatory to a contract can invalidate it by showing that his signature to the contract was made unintentionally or without full understanding of the implications.
words.name: non est factum

words.def: Reported by a sheriff on writ when the defendant cannot be found in his county or jurisdiction.
words.name: non est inventus

words.def: Performing some illegal action is not excused by the fact that a positive result came therefrom. Often used to argue that some forms of expression, such as graffiti or pornographic films, cannot be given the protection of law (e.g. copyright) as they are or may be considered illegal or morally reprehensible.
words.name: non faciat malum, ut inde veniat bonum

words.def: A type of verdict where positive guilt or innocence cannot be determined. Also called "not proven" in legal systems with such verdicts.
words.name: non liquet

words.def: A circumstance where the judge may override the jury verdict and reverse or modify the decision.
words.name: non obstante verdicto

words.def: a break in causation (and therefore probably liability) because something else has happened to remove the causal link
words.name: novus actus interveniens

words.def: An ambiguous word or term can be clarified by considering the whole context in which it is used, without having to define the term itself.
words.name: noscitur a sociis

words.def: A term used to direct the reader to cautionary or qualifying statements for the main text.
words.name: nota bene

words.def: An unenforceable promise, due to the absence of consideration or value exchanged for the promise.
words.name: nudum pactum

words.def: Notation made when a defendant has no tangible property available to be seized in order to comply with a judgement.
words.name: nulla bona

words.def: One cannot be prosecuted for doing something that is not prohibited by law.
words.name: nulla poena sine lege

words.def: One cannot be prosecuted for doing something that was not prohibited by law at the time and place it was committed, notwithstanding laws made since that time. A form of prohibition on retroactive laws.
words.name: nullum crimen, nulla poena sine praevia lege poenali

words.def: An action by a court to correct a previous procedural or clerical error.
words.name: nunc pro tunc

words.def: in law, an observation by a judge on some point of law not directly relevant to the case before him, and thus neither requiring his decision nor serving as a precedent, but nevertheless of persuasive authority. In general, any comment, remark or observation made in passing
words.name: obiter dictum

words.def: Burden of proof
words.name: onus probandi

words.def: A fundamental principle of law
words.name: pacta sunt servanda

words.def: Used when both parties to a dispute are at fault
words.name: par delictum

words.def: Refers to the power of the State to act as parent to a child when the legal parents are unable or unwilling.
words.name: parens patriae

words.def: Equal ranking, equal priority (usually referring to creditors)
words.name: pari passu

words.def: The head of household, for purposes of considering the rights and responsibilities thereof. (Civil law) bonus paterfamilias: a standard of care equivalent to the common law ordinary reasonable man.
words.name: pater familias

words.def: Court orders used to provide relief until the final judgement is rendered. Commonly used in divorce proceedings. The adverbial form of lis pendens (above).
words.name: pendente lite

words.def: dividing money up strictly and equally according to the number of beneficiaries
words.name: per capita

words.def: Legal shorthand for "in contrast to"
words.name: per contra

words.def: A decision delivered by a multi-judge panel, such as an appellate court, in which the decision is said to be authored by the court itself, instead of situations where those individual judges supporting the decision are named.
words.name: per curiam

words.def: A judgement given without reference to precedent.
words.name: per incuriam

words.def: Used as a defense, when illegal acts were performed under duress
words.name: per minas

words.def: Employed when an adult brings suit on behalf of a minor, who was unable to maintain an action on his own behalf at common law.
words.name: per proxima amici

words.def: Used in legal documents in the same sense as "whereby". A per quod statement is typically used to show that specific acts had consequences which form the basis for the legal action.
words.name: per quod

words.def: Something that is, as a matter of law.
words.name: per se

words.def: An estate of a decedent is distributed per stirpes, if each branch of the family is to receive an equal share of an estate.
words.name: per stirpes

words.def: A condition given to support requests for urgent action, such as a protective order or restraining order.
words.name: periculum in mora

words.def: A person who is officially considered unwelcome by a host country in which they are residing in a diplomatic capacity. The person is typically expelled to their home country.
words.name: persona non grata

words.def: A body of armed citizens pressed into service by legal authority, to keep the peace or pursue a fugitive.
words.name: posse comitatus

words.def: Refers to an autopsy, or as a qualification as to when some event occurred.
words.name: post mortem

words.def: Used in reference to intellectual property rights, which usually are based around the author's lifetime.
words.name: post mortem auctoris

words.def: The Roman praetor (magistrate) responsible for matters involving non-Romans.
words.name: praetor peregrinus

words.def: A matter that appears to be sufficiently based in the evidence as to be considered true.
words.name: prima facie

words.def: (1) A legal principle that older laws take precedence over newer ones. Another name for this principle is lex posterior. (2) (Scots law, civil law), usually translated as "prior in time, superior in right", the principle that someone who registers (a security interest) earlier therefore ranks higher than other creditors.
words.name: prior tempore potior iure

words.def: Professional work done for free.
words.name: pro bono

words.def: Things done as formalities.
words.name: pro forma

words.def: Refers to a lawyer who is allowed to participate (only) in a specific case, despite being in a jurisdiction in which he has not been generally admitted
words.name: pro hac vice

words.def: Representing oneself, without counsel. Also known as pro se representation.
words.name: pro per

words.def: A calculation adjusted based on a proportional value relevant to the calculation. An example would be a tenant being charged a portion of a month's rent based on having lived there less than a full month. The amount charged would be proportional to the time occupied.
words.name: pro rata

words.def: Representing oneself, without counsel. Also known as pro per representation.
words.name: pro se

words.def: A partial payment of an award or claim, based on the defendant's ability to pay.
words.name: pro tanto

words.def: Something, such as an office held, that is temporary.
words.name: pro tem

words.def: Something, such as an office held, that is temporary.
words.name: pro tempore

words.def: Refers to one reperesenting themselves without the services of a lawyer. Also known as pro per representation.
words.name: propria persona

words.def: Used to cite something that has already been admitted into the record. It was frequently used in pleadings, generally abbreviated "prout &c.", to indicate that a fact was supported by documentary evidence. Failure to use this phrase correctly could be a fatal defect and so cause a case to fail.[6]
words.name: prout patet per recordum

words.def: In the capacity of
words.name: qua

words.def: The question is raised. Used to declare that a question is being asked in the following verbiage.
words.name: quareitur

words.def: Used in legal drafts to call attention to some uncertainty or inconsistency in the material being cited.
words.name: quaere

words.def:
In contract law, a quasi-contractual remedy that permits partial reasonable payment for an incomplete piece of work (services and/or materials), assessed proportionately, where no price is established when the request is made.[3]
In contract law, and in particular the requirement for consideration, if no fixed price is agreed upon for the service and/or materials, then one party would request a reasonable price for the said services and/or materials at the end of the job. A common example would be a plumber requested to fix a leak in the middle of the night.[3]
words.name: quantum meruit

words.def:
Under Common Law, a remedy to compute reasonable damages when a contract has been breached – the implied promise of payment of a reasonable price for goods.
In contract law, for requirements of consideration, reasonable worth for goods delivered.
Usage: quantum meruit has replaced quantum valebant in consideration;[3] in the case of contract remedy, quantum valebant is being used less, and could be considered obsolete.
words.name: quantum valebant

words.def: Resembling or being similar to something, without actually being that thing.
words.name: quasi

words.def: One who delegates a task to another, takes full responsibility for the performance of that act as if he himself had done it. Basis for the law of agency
words.name: qui facit per alium facit per se

words.def: In a qui tam action, one who assists the prosecution of a case is entitled to a proportion of any fines or penalties assessed.
words.name: qui tam

words.def: An equal exchange of goods or services, or of money (or other consideration of equal value) for some goods or services.
words.name: quid pro quo

words.def: Returning to a specific state of affairs which preceded some defined action.
words.name: quo ante

words.def: A request made to someone exercising some power, to show by what legal right they are exercising that power. A type of writ.
words.name: quo warranto

words.def: Used to mean "with respect to" some named thing, such as when stating what the law is in regards to that named thing.
words.name: quoad hoc

words.def: King or Queen. In British cases, will see R v Freeman meaning Regina against Freeman. Changes with King or Queen on throne at time.
words.name: R

words.def: The point in a legal proceeding, or the legal precedent so involved, which led to the final decision being what it was.
words.name: ratio decidendi

words.def: The popular opinion of Roman law, held by those in the Medieval period.
words.name: ratio scripta

words.def: "Certain rights may arise by virtue of ownership of the soil upon which wild animals are found."[2]
words.name: rationae soli

words.def: A qualification in a treaty or contract, that allows for nullification in the event fundamental circumstances change.
words.name: rebus sic stantibus

words.def: The canon of construction that in a list of items containing a qualifying phrase at the end, the qualifier refers only to the last item in the list.
words.name: reddendo singula singulis

words.def: Property constructs like airspace and water rights are said to be res communis – that is, a thing common to all, and that could not be the subject of ownership. With airspace, the difficulty has been to identify where the fee simple holder's rights to the heavens end. Water is a bit more defined – it is common until captured.[2]
words.name: res communis

words.def: Differing meaning depending on what type of law is involved. May refer to the complete act of a felony, from start to finish, or may refer to statements given that may be exempt from hearsay rules.
words.name: res gestae

words.def: used in tort law when there is no proof of what caused the harm, but it is most likely only the thing that could have caused the harm
words.name: res ipsa loquitur

words.def: A matter that has been finally adjudicated, meaning no further appeals or legal actions by the involved parties is now possible.
words.name: res judicata

words.def: Ownerless property or goods. Such property or goods are able and subject to being owned by anybody.
words.name: res nullius

words.def: All things subject to concern by the citizenry. The root of the word republic.
words.name: res publica

words.def: All things of concern to the worldwide body of Christianity
words.name: res publica christiana

words.def: A concept that the master (e.g. employer) is responsible for the actions of his subordinates (e.g. employees).
words.name: respondeat superior

words.def:
(1) Restoration of something, such as a building or damaged property, to its original condition.
(2) In contract law, when considering breach of contract and remedies, to restore a party to an original position.[3]
words.name: restitutio in integrum

words.def: Used to describe the basis for sovereign immunity
words.name: rex non potest peccare

words.def: Used variously as a motto, a reminder, or a notion of how the law and governments in general should be.
words.name: salus populi suprema lex esto

words.def: Defamation against a peer in British law. Now repealed as a specific offense.
words.name: scandalum magnatum

words.def: Used when offenses or torts were committed with the full awareness of the one so committing.
words.name: scienter

words.def: A writ, directing local officials to officially inform a party of official proceedings concerning them.
words.name: scire facias

words.def: The official response of the official serving a writ of scire facias, informing the court that the writ has been properly delivered.
words.name: scire feci

words.def: The act of defending one's own person or property, or the well-being or property of another.
words.name: se defendendo

words.def: Describes the process in which the court hears assorted matters in a specific order. Also refers to an occasion where a multiple-judge panel will issue individual opinions from the members, rather than a single ruling from the entire panel.
words.name: seriatim

words.def: While an individual is entitled to the use and enjoyment of one's estate, the right is not without limits. Restrictions can give rise to tort actions include trespass, negligence, strict liability, and nuisance.[2]
words.name: sic utere tuo ut alienum non laedas

words.def: Used when the court is adjourning without specifying a date to re-convene. See also adjournment sine die.
words.name: sine die

words.def: Refers to some essential event or action, without which there can be no specified consequence.
words.name: sine qua non

words.def: Used to refer to laws specific to the location where specific property exists, or where an offense or tort was committed.
words.name: situs

words.def: Undue performance or payment, obliging the enrichee (accipiens) to return the undue payment or compensate the impoverishee (solvens) for the undue performance
words.name: solutio indebiti

words.def: The obligation of a judge to stand by a prior precedent.
words.name: stare decisis

words.def: In contract law, in a case of innocent representation, the injured party is entitled to be replaced in statu quo. Note the common usage is status quo from the Latin status quo ante, the "state in which before" or "the state of affairs that existed previously."[3]
words.name:
status quo
status quo ante
statu quo

words.def:
1) In property law, condominiums has said to occupy stratum many stories about the ground.[2]
2) Stratum can also be a societial level made up of individuals with similar status of social, cultural or economic nature.
3) Stratum can refer to classification in an organized system along the lines of layers, levels, divisions, or similar grouping.
words.name: stratum

words.def: Some action taken by the public prosecutor or another official body, without the prompting of a plaintiff or another party. (compare ex proprio motu, ex mero motu which are used for courts)
words.name: sua sponte

words.def: Refers to a matter currently being considered by the court.
words.name: sub judice

words.def: Term in contract law that allows limited modifications to a contract after the original form has been agreed to by all parties.
words.name: sub modo

words.def: Abbreviated sub nom.; used in case citations to indicate that the official name of a case changed during the proceedings, usually after appeal (e.g., rev'd sub nom. and aff'd sub nom.)
words.name: sub nomine

words.def: A ruling, order, or other court action made without specifically stating the ruling, order, or action. The effect of the ruling or action is implied by related and subsequent actions, but not specifically stated.
words.name: sub silentio

words.def: A writ compelling testimony, the production of evidence, or some other action, under penalty for failure to do so.
words.name: subpoena

words.def: An order compelling an entity to give oral testimony in a legal matter.
words.name: subpoena ad testificandum

words.def: An order compelling an entity to produce physical evidence or witness in a legal matter.
words.name: subpoena duces tecum

words.def: A false statement made in the negotiation of a contract.
words.name: suggestio falsi

words.def: Something that is unique amongst a group.
words.name: sui generis

words.def: Refers to one legally competent to manage his own affairs. Also spelled sui iuris.
words.name: sui juris

words.def: Refers to a court or other official agency taking some action on its own accord (synonyms: ex proprio motu, ex mero motu). Similar to sua sponte.
words.name: suo motu

words.def: A bond tendered by an appellant as surety to the court, requesting a delay of payment for awards or damages granted, pending the outcome of the appeal.
words.name: supersedeas

words.def: Willful concealment of the truth when bound to reveal it, such as withholding details of damage from an auto accident from a prospective buyer of the car in that accident.
words.name: suppressio veri

words.def: Used in citations to refer to a previously cited source.
words.name: supra

words.def: (Scots law) "as is", to disclaim implied warranties, as in to purchase or convey something tantum et tale
words.name: tantum et tale

words.def: Land that has never been part of a sovereign state, or land which a sovereign state has relinquished claim to.
words.name: terra nullius

words.def: A completely new trial of a matter previously judged. It specifically refers to a replacement trial for the previous one, and not an appeal of the previous decision.
words.name: trial de novo

words.def: Refers to a threefold tax levied on Anglo-Saxon citizens to cover roads, buildings, and the military.
words.name: trinoda necessitas

words.def: Concept in contract law specifying that all parties must act with the utmost good faith.
words.name: uberrima fides

words.def: Specifies that one should do what he can to support the community, but since everyone has different levels of ability, it cannot be expected that all will perform the same.
words.name: ultra posse nemo obligatur

words.def: An act that requires legal authority to perform, but which is done without obtaining that authority.
words.name: ultra vires

words.def: Aggregate of people, body corporate, as in a college, corporation, or state
words.name: universitas personarum

words.def: Aggregate of things
words.name: universitas rerum

words.def: Used to criticize inconsistencies in speech or testimony, as in: one says one thing, and in the same breath, says another contradictory thing.
words.name: uno flatu

words.def: Ancient concept regarding conflicts, wherein all property possessed by the parties at the conclusion of the conflict shall remain owned by those parties unless treaties to the contrary are enacted.
words.name: uti possidetis

words.def: Used in documents in place of the wife's name. Usually abbreviated et ux.
words.name: uxor

words.def: Used when considering whether some event or situation is either present or it is not.
words.name: vel non

words.def: The power of an executive to prevent an action, especially the enactment of legislation.
words.name: veto

words.def: Something that is the same either way.
words.name: vice versa

words.def: Used in citations to refer the reader to another location.
words.name: vide

words.def: Used in documents to mean "namely" or "that is". Usually abbreviated viz.
words.name: videlicet

words.def: Something which is legally binding.
words.name: vinculum juris

words.def: Force majeure, specifically events over which no humans have control, and so cannot be held responsible. Equivalent to an "Act of God". Compare casus fortuitus (see above).
words.name: vis major

words.def: Namely
words.name: viz.

words.def: Notion that a person cannot bring a claim against another for injury, if said person willingly placed themselves in a situation where they knew injury could result.
words.name: volenti non fit injuria

words.def: Concept that if an opposing party unreasonably delays bringing an action, that it is no longer considered just to hear their claim, due to fundamental changes in circumstance brought upon by their delay.
words.name: vigilantibus non dormientibus aequitas subvenit
